reviewText: Goran and Sven have been given the O.K. for the adoption process and are expecting a baby, 1.5 years old.  They live together in a nice, surrealistic white picket fence neighborhood with beautiful flowering yards.  When they receive the notice of a baby named Patrik, they prepare the nursery and all is well, including their relationship.However, a young troubled, homophobic teen arrives on their doorstep, and in waiting for their own child, they house the poor lad for a spell.  Apparently, a typo has caused the confusion.  During the wait for the correct child to arrive, the couple harbors Patrik til their prospective child arrives.  But the drama created with this unruly troublesome teen splits the two apart.  Sven, a drinker, is asked to leave the home, while Goran takes to bonding with Patrik.This is a feel good family film, and by family film, I mean a loving couple wanting to adopt.  There are a couple of passionate scenes some people may want to be warned about.  And, if you have young children, you may need to have them out of the room, or prepare them.What struck me about this Swedish film was the neighborhood, looking colorful and almost surreal. There isn't anything completely new about the film, just another manner in which the story is told.  It is with some light humor, and considered a light drama.  .....Enjoyable, Rizzo
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was actually surprised at how well this film was made.  It sounded like it would be entertaining just for the fact of the age of the boy to be adopted being 15 instead of 1.5.  Top that with him being homophobic and it could have been a terrible movie if not done right.  Fortunately, it was done very, very well and ends up being a touching story about a boy needing a family and they needing him.

reviewText: I have read through the reviews which precede mine, and I see that they are all enthusiastic and positive and complimentary towards a "gay" film which extends its vision well beyond the hackneyed themes associated with the majority of films of this genre.Basically the film is very well cast, and the crucial role of Patrik, played by Tom Ljungman (who turns 20 this year, and who has acted in numerous Swedish TV series - and had a very small role in Let the Right One In) is beautifully realised - and beautifully written of course. There is nothing heavy handed about the script - there is no proselytising - everything unfolds at its own gentle and infectious pace.The film is based on a play by Michael Druker and the play is no doubt excellent, the film exceptional.You won't get any Bonus Material with the DVD - but the Chapter Headings are very good!! If you believe that Trailers count as Bonus Material, you get Fruit Fly, Leo's Room, Twisted Romance and Raging Sun Raging Sky.These are all quite dischordant with the gentle and sympathetic strains of Patrik Age 1,5
summary: Great film, great script, great cast.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Patrik, Age 1.5" is a fine small film from Sweden that has some great things to say about compassion, honesty in relationships and seeing past stereotypes.  The film has a marvelous cast and is deftly directed by Ella Lemhagen.  In a nutshell, "Patrik" is the story of a gay professional couple (Goran and Sven), living a "straight" suburbanite life style, who apply to the local social services administration to adopt a baby.  Their application is approved, but even in socially progressive Sweden, babies are rarely placed with gay adoptive parents.  Out of the blue, the disappointed couple is informed that they have been chosen to parent Patrik, a 1.5 year old boy with a troubled past.  When Patrik arrives at their door, Goran and Sven discover that the letter from social services contained a small typo and that Patrik is actually a 15 year old with serious attitude, including some strongly stated homophobic bias.  As the couple tries to rectify what they perceive as an error, a bonding process with Patrik begins.  Goran, the more domestic  and nurturing member of the couple, in particular begins to see Patrik's situation with compassion.  His partner, Sven, is rapidly moving in the opposite direction and eventually precipitates a split when he repudiates the whole domestic setup.  The rest of the film is about the growth of the two adults as human beings and the adolescent Patrik into a trusting young adult.The cast of "Patrik" is uniformly excellent and the actors relate well and credibly to each other.  The real standouts in the film are Gustaf Skarsgard, who plays the ever optimistic and loving Goran and Tom Ljungman  who plays Patrik of the title role.  Skarsgard gives Goran emotional strength and humanity that prevails against the several crises that are written into the script.  Goran is able to endure everyday homophobia, a partner with a lot of baggage (history of alcohol abuse, inability to emotionally commit, etc.) and a host of bureaucratic obstacles in pursuit of parenthood.  Over the course of the film, he has the audience completely in his pocket, even when he gives up something that he wants very much in order to do the right thing for someone he loves.This is a sweet and effecting film that will require at least one handkerchief for most viewers.  Highly recommended.
summary: Blessed typo - a big-hearted and wonderfully entertaining film from Sweden
Title: N/A

reviewText: Goran and Sven are a married gay couple, "out" to their heterosexual neighbors in a Swedish version of the Desperate Housewives' Wisteria Lane. They are anxiously awaiting the results of their application to adopt a baby, to make their family complete, and have set up a cute nursery for him/her. First, they are told that there are no young children available to a gay couple, then are sent a notice that they can adopt "Patrik, Age 1.5" (2008) ... which they take to mean one and half years old.  They quickly agree, and are in for a surprise, when it turns out their young charge is actually fifteen years old, a juvenile delinquent and petty thief who has robbed people at knifepoint. This turns out to be the only child available, and, although neither of the men is happy about this (and neither is Patrik, who is quite homophobic), Goran pushes to let Patrik stay with them until another suitable couple is found.  Sven can't deal with that, and leaves Goran, just as he left his wife and daughter when he first took up with Goran.A rather simplistic story, but told beautifully here, with realism, pathos and just enough comic relief.  The way that the couple gets to know Patrik, and vice versa, can be a lesson for mainstream America to live together despite our natural diversity.  In Swedish with English subtitles, not rated (but would be an R for content), extras on DVD limited to chapter stops and trailer.  This is a keeper, five stars out of five.
summary: Sweet, romantic tale of a gay couple's adoption quest.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This film is really worth your time.  It's about family, about bonds, about love and relationships.  It's about neighbors and community.  It's about respect and prejudice, and changing the way people think and act.  The story revolves around a gay male couple recently moved into their suburban home full of 'traditional straight familes'.  Intent of adopting a baby, a mix-up occurs and they end up with 15-year old Patrik - troubled, and abused by a failed adoption/foster care system.  This homophobic young lad unintentionally wrecks havoc on the home life of Goran and Sven.  As the film unfolds, we learn just how much an open-mind and giving heart can change the way people think.  With dramatic moments, the story adds just enough laughs - so at worst, you may be laughing through your tears.  I won't give away the ending, but at least it's as positive as it can be without being too 'Brady Bunch' perfect.  The movie is a reminder to us all in this day and age that there is no room for hate.  Love comes from withn and is infectious.  The movie is in Swedish with English Subtitles.
summary: Sweet, Sad, Funny - A Must See

reviewText: It should be noted that films are designed to be seen by more than just one person at a time.  That always improves the experience.  This film was no exception.  Upon viewing as part of a group, it unfurls many levels that had gone unnoticed."Patrik 1,5" is a Swedish film with English subtitles made in 2008.  A gay couple adopting a child!  The child turns out not to be a 1  year old, but rather a 15 year old troublemaker with a criminal record.Wonderful set up!  This is a story whose time has come.  Who care's if the ending is predictable and characters, at times, follow stereotypes.  It's enjoyable to see different viewpoints offered by other cultures.  The sub titles can be over come.  However other flaws in the film created an uncomfortable first viewing experience.Having no idea of the body of work from the principles involved, it is hard to say if it is the writing, directing or acting that is weak.The part of Sven, played by Torkel Petersson comes off as a jerk, an alcoholic, and a generally mean guy, who dramatically changes, (for no apparent reason), to make the ending of the film make sense. One wishes this part had been "fleshed-out" a bit more.Interestingly the other half of the couple: Goran, played by Gustaf Skarsgrd seems almost too good to be true.  In another review here on Amazon.com, Goran was described as the "stay at home mom" ignoring the fact that the character is a working medical doctor!  Wow, the 21st. century and they still try to make us fit into their straight roles.After they find Patrik, their adopted baby is really a 15 year old boy; they leave a video monitor on to watch him.  At first that bothered me.  Now if we were to see the "monitor" as a metaphor for parenting, then it casts a much more comfortable and intriguing factor into the mix.By the same token Patrik, played by Tom Ljungman, turns out to have a gift at gardening.  A trait that might be seen in itself as a form of parenting.This could have been made as a great screwball romantic comedy. It could have been an insightful documentary.  As a drama, it could have delved into the dynamic of a couple who have different levels of maturity.However this films best effort was showing all of the prejudices found in even the most liberal of societies.  On the surface Patrik 1,5 is about gay parenting.  Beneath it is really about relationships and societies expectations.I would suggest the film "Breakfast with Scot" as a more focused alternative on the topic of Gay parenting.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is truly an incredible film! The acting is superb by all three main cast members: Goran (Gustaf Skarsgrd), Sven (Torkel Petersson) and Patrik (Tom Ljungman). Goran and Sven, a gay couple have moved to a quaint neighborhood in the burbs in preparation for the arrival of their newly adopted son Patrik, however they are not to have the 1.5 year old baby they are planning for. A slight typo carries with it a whole lot of surprises with their new child, a not so typical 15 year old boy with a very checkered past. His mother died while he was a baby and no one else has ever been able to tame this troubled wild child. Having spent most of his life in a boy's home, he has no idea what love is and he's convinced he doesn't want any part of it. That isn't the ONLY thing he doesn't want any part of! Living with "Homo's" isn't exactly Patriks cup of tea, and he's not going to be shy about his feelings on the subject.Upon Patriks arrival, everything goes topsy turvy and the adventure begins. The relationship of Goran and Sven is tested to the breaking point, and the two part ways. Goran is left to handle Patrik, the homo-hating thug, who quickly learns to manipulate his new trustee. Just when it appears that life couldn't get much worse, something very unexpected happens; a funny little thing called love. But even love may have a little trouble tackling the heart of a child who never felt it and repair the damage that's been done to a once perfect relationship.The music is in english and sets the scene well for the scope of the film. Picture and sound quality are excellent and the scenery is beautiful, although parts of it resemble something you'd expect from the movie "Pleasantville" or the 1950's sit-com "leave it to Beaver". At first I wasn't sure about the casting of the parts of Goran and Sven. They didn't seem to have what it took to make a believable couple, however it didn't take long for that opinion to change. Wonderful acting by both, and Tom Ljungman done a remarkable job playing the role of Patrik. I anticipate future films with this kid. He has a natural talent for acting and will win your heart in a flash. A great mix of home-spun Americana, nostalgia, romance, comedy, drama, adventure and intrigue. This movie may well become one of my top ten favorites. Well worth purchasing to watch over and over again. I'd give it three thumbs up, but I'd have to borrow a thumb.
summary: "No, I really want to have a dog".

reviewText: This is a wonderful film that follows a very good storyline and treats the characters in a realistic and reasonable way.  The characters and the situations are both believable and played honestly.  It avoids the need for the gratuitous sex scenes that seem to be requisite parts of so many badly made gay themed films.  It also acknowledges that while gay marriage may be legal in Sweden, all is not perfect.  The film contains little snippets of the characters' lives that are not directly related to the storyline in a specific way, yet reinforce the story arc quite well.The subtitles present dialogue translation quite effectively without being imposing, making the film entirely enjoyable even though it is in Swedish.  The comedic moment play thorough, and in the more serious and emotional scenes, nothing is lost.  I expected it to be a fairly pedestrian comedy and it turned out to be much more.
summary: If only US filmmakers could do so well

reviewText: I have never had bad words to say about purchasing from Amazon and I have purchased a large amount of DVD's.In this instant I didn't read the movie reviews (I often don't and have never been caught out as I have beenthis time)Since putting the movie on to watch I was surprised and disapointed in what I had received. It was onlythen that I logged into my account, read the reviews and discovered the mistake I had made which could have easilybeen avoided. The storyline sounded fantastic after reading this and I'm saddened I will besubtitles. I am not a person who can follow a movie with subtitles as well as concentrate on the movie.If I could recommend that Amazon (or their affiliates) write 'foreign subtitled film' on the first page, it wouldmake our choices much easier and prevent having to make returns. We do get a RED comment when items are not shippedto our countries region. Maybe the same could be done for non English speaking movies.I have nothing but praise for Amazon. I am a loyal customer and choose to always stay this way.RegardsGraham

reviewText: I love this movie...The experience of a gay couple getting the wrong Patrik! - Instead of a baby 1.5 years old, they got a teenager 15 years old with bad records. Apart from that, Goran is eager to have kid but Sven not as eager as him which will become problem in their relatonship. I really enjoy this movie- The different feelings, expressions and actings between the two toward the teenager are great. Sven being drunk is funny and I love the soft side of his partner. The sex scenes are not too much and not less- just nice and lovely. The storyline and cinematography are good. I really enjoy this movie.Some things make me scratch my head though- i) how far is Sven relationship with the other guy. That dude clearly got a thing for Sven. The movie just wave that little thing off- or maybe it just about it- It should have been more clear though.... ii) What did Sven said to Goran after he call him to talk?? Even though I can put 2 and 2 together but to watch it reveal on screen would be wonderful consider how well the script, cinematography and the acting are.

reviewerName: Jacques COULARDEAU "A soul doctor, so to say"
reviewText: A film all based on qui pro quos. A gay married couple in Sweden comes into a new neighbourhood. Goran is a doctor and Sven is his husband. They were accepted for adoption but they were finally answered that no country in the world accepts to entrust a child for adoption to a homosexual couple. The deception is great but one day a letter arrives from social services. It contains a mistake and they are announced they will get a child of 1.5 years of age, Patrik is his name.Unluckily the kid that arrives is in fact 15, mother dead, father unknown, ten years in foster homes and institutions, a lot of delinquent acts, etc. Sven panics completely whereas Goran accepts the child, or rather teenager. Strangely enough Patrik is going to help Goran and Sven get accepted in the neighbourhood because he becomes the gardener of everyone, for money of course, and he becomes the skateboard coach of the kids in the street, etc.The end is a happy ending of course and it is not the real interest of the film. The real interest is to show that after and beyond all kinds of prejudices people deeply need at any age simple contact with others, contact that is called love and that it has nothing to do with sex really. Love is the food of angels and all children, and all people should be angels and get their ration, and even more that that everyday, of love.And it is so simple at times to find what can give someone the certainty they are loved, the guarantee they will be loved. Of course it is not simple and it cannot be easy to do but it is needed, provided people get out of their fears and fear is bigotry most of the time. We have no reason to be afraid of anything. To give a child one's own shirt for that child to look good when he needs to look good is more important than all the treasures of Arabia.That's the message of this film, and as such it works marvellously.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU
Title: N/A

reviewText: This charming Swedish film (English captions) brings us an authentic gay couple, stable, married and ready to start a family. They jump through all the bureaucratic hoops and are finally notified that their child is ready: his name is Patrik and he is 1.5 years old. They expect Social Services to bring the tyke to their house - the nursery is painted, the crib is draped in netting, there is a rocking horse and an upholstered chair, plus a closed-circuit baby monitor.Instead, a 15-year-old rebel shows up on their doorstep, his age was a typo. Patrik has been shoved around the foster-care circuit for 10 years, so he is angry and defiant. Furthermore, he has no use for "homos!"This is only the tip of the iceberg as we watch a richly textured story unfold, with half a dozen really nice people (and a few not quite so nice) try their best to sort out the bungle and make some sense out of this poor kid's life.The Swedish cast is excellent and I liked the Dolly Parton music, too!
Title: N/A

reviewText: ***** REVISED RATING - SEE NOTE BELOW *****This is a very, very sweet, very, very unreal movie. It reminds me a lot of a generic romantic comedy from the 1930s, when Hollywood's bread and butter was helping people escape from the brutality of the Great Depression into a magical world in which overwhelming obstacles were always overcome, troublesome heroes always turned out to have hearts of gold, and everything came up roses in the end.In fact, this movie could have been made almost exactly the same in 1936, with Mickey Rooney playing the adorable bad boy and his prospective parents any two from the studios' stable of romantic comedy duos. Of course, Göran would be a woman instead of a man, but if they made Sven an ex-con they could get the same degree of social stigma as a gay couple has today and not have to change one word of dialog. Patrik would box instead of doing martial arts and skateboarding, but they wouldn't even have to change Sven's vice, since alcohol was the vice of choice 75 years ago too, not the cocaine or other snortable drug that's more common in movies today.I'm not saying I didn't enjoy this movie, because I did, but anybody on earth who thinks there's anything remotely true or relevant in this story is living in a dream world. It's pure escapism, which is great as long as we remember that's what it is.*****After further reflection I have raised the rating from three stars to five. The sweetness and warmth of this movie far outshine its unreality, and it's better than any of the 1930s Hollywood movies I was comparing it to. Even though the story is completely unreal, the wonderful feelings it produces are very real, very valuable, and especially welcome in the context of a gay marriage.
summary: A sweet, unreal revival of a 1930s Hollywood staple
Title: N/A

reviewText: .....guy....this Goran....this Gustaf Skarsgard....this standout performer.After all, it is this actor who is the heart and the soul of this story-with-a-twist.  Here's a performer whose every thought is readable in his face....whose every emotion makes its way across to us.  And you know what's special about this?  It's that no one can just "act" these things; these are things you have to "be" within yourself.  I think the Skarsgard we see onscreen is the very same man off screen---and who of us wouldn't want a someone like that?And if Skarsgard is all of that, then it is Tom Ljungman, as Patrik, who is the zest and the vitality of this movie....the one who gels it all.  Wherever Sweden was able to come up with such an accomplished SIXTEEN year old is beyond me.  The only thing left to say about this young man is: "Gustaf Skarsgard, you'd better watch out; someone is hard on your heels."Oh, and I don't think any of us would kick a Torkel Petersson (Sven) out of....ahem...., either.Postscript for The Wonderful Director (Underbar Direktör):  Dear Ella Lemhagen....The ONLY thing this most satisfied movie viewer could think of to change in this exceptional film would be the Closing Credits and its "Crosscountry Run."  Of course, you know the place I mean (new viewers will have to see it for themselves).  Full of Piss + Vinegar Patrik (Age 1.5) would be in the "leading lane".....followed closely by Daddy Goran.....then Papa Sven.....and bringing up the rear, daughter Isabell (who can even keep Patrik on his toes).(( Be sure and grab a look at the overlooked "Handsome Harry" starring TV's Jamey Sheridan and filmdom's Steve Buscemi.  Also, try the unusual "From Beginning to End".  I've got reviews here for both of them ))
summary: Who of us couldn't fall in love with this......

reviewText: "Patrik Age 1.5" tells the story of how one minor typographical error can change the lives of several people. It's a moving, sometimes funny, sometimes sad film about a gay couple in Sweden who want to adopt a baby. I hope that some potential viewers do not pass on this film thinking that it's a "gay" film. This film has universal appeal. It's real in its depiction of the acception by some and rejection by others of gay people. It shows how a gay couple struggle and deal with the same problems as straight couples, such as money, drinking, jealousy, but there is still a deep rooted love that binds them together. The film also shows the heartbreak of an abandoned teen. He comes off as tough as nails, filled with anger and hate. But it's just a disguise for a scared, sad, lonely boy who is deeply hurting, and desperately needs to be loved. One of the most heart warming, emotional films in recent memory, with just enough comedy elements to keep it light and very amusing. I'm surprised this film didn't get an Oscar nomination for Best Foreign Language Film for 2008. It certaily deserved one.

reviewText: I have to admit I fell in love with the character Goran. The actor playing that character did a fine job. I loved his gentle, caring nature. When he got angry at his neighbor for their boorish attitude he ripped up their flowerbed then seeing what he had done he put it all back together. His facial expressions were so genuine and believable. He had me in tears on one ocassion. All of this fine movie was  helped along with the beautiful country music score. One reviewer wrote he couldn't understand why Sven changed..... I can.... he loved that loveable teddy bear Goran and realized what he had thrown away.  Don't miss this one folks. I hope Hollywood doesn't try to do an English Language remake... they would never do justice to the original.
summary: Superb acting... great feel good story!

reviewText: This film touches on question of whether gay love can form a permanent bond between two people and whether it can form the foundation for a family.  Is gay love strong enough to form a family and hold it together or can only straight love do that?In the film, a gay couple wants to adopt a baby.  A "mistake" in a social service agency form sends a 15 year old rather than a 1.5 year old to the couple.  The mistake turns into a tragedy because the 15 year old, named Patrik, is a homophobe scared to death of the couple and the couple is scared to death of Patrik.The couple wants to send Patrik back to the agency and Patrik definitely wants to get away from the couple.  The story is brilliant in that it keeps you guessing and evokes tears and laughter -- often at the same time.  The story moves so well and seems so authentic that I was never bored.  I am glad I bought this DVD and I will watch it again and again because the film is so entertaining.

reviewText: I was half expecting this to be another horrible gay themed movie with shallow looking people in shallow life situations with a happy ending. It does follow some of the tropes; the happy ending, but it is also quite an endearing film with great performances from all involved. Gustaf who plays Goran (the wife role in the gay relationship) is so cute and charming. Its hard not to feel anything for him because he is the heart of the movie. The kid Patrik is also pretty good as the troubled teen with homophobic views who grows into a likable brat. I had an issue with the character of Sven, he seems to have two personalities that change depending on the situation but thats a small quibble for a fine film.BTW, Gustaf is the brother of True Blood's Alexander Skarsgard.P.S. This is a foreign language film with subtitles that might turn off some people.

reviewText: I absolutely love this movie.  I saw it on Netflix and it became one of my favorite movies.  Its a feel good movie.Basically its a story about 2 men Goran and Sven (Goran who is a total sweetheart who really wants a kid and a happy involved life in the suburbs and Sven, a divorcee with a daughter that he wasnt ready to be a parent with and a drinking problem hes never firmly put a stop to and cant seem to quit smoking). Goran and Sven want to adopt a baby (well, moreso Goran but Svens going along with it and trying to act excited about it) and they think everythings going just fine but when they show up after being cleared for adoption they find out that they aren't okayed for adoption because they are a gay couple.  They decide they'll try for adopting a swedish child and through a typo they, believing they are adopting a 1 and a half year old tike named Patrik are actually adopting a 15 year old homophobic teenager with a violent past with a criminal record.  As they try and get rid of Patrik Gorans parenting nature kicks in and he tries to reach out to the boy through Patriks interest in gardening and Sven finds Patriks too much to bother.I dont want to tell much more than that but its not as predictable as I thought it would be.  There are a number of turns and twists.  Goran was a breath of fresh air and Patrik stole my heart.  I also liked Svens ex wife who is so unselfish about the situationI could watch this little gem over and over again.
